verb.description: Take (another person's property) without permission or legal right and without intending to return it.
examples: she was found guilty of stealing from her employers
he stole down to the kitchen
a delicious languor was stealing over her

phrases: Still, almost every week, various baddies steal Jimmy blind and threaten to bring down plague.
I'd better get back on the floor before those raccoons steal me blind.
But again, the staff of the hotel didn't merely steal me blind.
Even as the bandits and kidnappers find creatively hideous ways of earning a better living, we have among us corporate crooks who are stealing us blind.
The fear he inspires is not that he will steal you blind and corrupt your morals.
origin: Old English stelan (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch stelen and German stehlen.
